content:
• Tuesday, January 20, 2015
  • FEYE

    FireEye, KEYW rise ahead of State of the Union

    • FireEye (NASDAQ:FEYE) is up 2.9% AH, and KEYW Holding up 2.8%, ahead of Pres. Obama's State of the Union (set for 9PM ET). The companies respectively rose 2% and 2.1% in regular trading.
    • Obama is widely expected to discuss a series of cybersecurity and identity theft/privacy legislative proposals and executive actions during his speech. The White House has been previewing its proposals in advance.
    • Last week: Cybersecurity stocks gain on pending Obama proposals
     
     
     
     
    | 7:24 PM | 1 Comment
  • BHP

    BHP to shut down 40% of its U.S. shale wells

    • BHP Billiton (NYSE:BHP) says it will shut down 40% of its U.S. shale oil rigs by the end of its fiscal year.
    • BHP plans to pare the number of rigs it is using in the U.S. to 16 from 26, focusing on drilling in the liquids-rich Black Hawk basin while cutting back in the Permian and Hawkville acreage; it says it will provide more details on its revised shale drilling budget, originally set at $4B for this financial year, next month.
    • Also, BHP says its iron ore output climbed 16% to 56.35M metric tons in the December quarter, and reaffirmed it would boost annual output by 11% in the fiscal year to June 2015 to 225M metric tons; petroleum production for the quarter rose 10% Y/Y to 63.6M boe.
    • Earlier: BHP seen slashing U.S. shale spending to shore up dividend promise
     
     
     
     
    | 7:23 PM | 1 Comment

  • After Hour Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: NFLX +13.3%. WWD +12.4%. CONN +10.2%. MACK +6.6%. CREE +6.2%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: ARNA -7.2%. NVAX -6.4%. ILMN -6.3%. ACTG -6.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 4 Comments
  • CREE

    Cree +4.1% AH on FQ2 beat, solid FQ3 guidance

    • CREE expects FQ3 revenue of $395M-$415M vs. a $404.2M consensus. EPS guidance of $0.21-$0.25 is $0.02 above a $0.21 consensus at the midpoint.
    • FQ2 gross margin was 33.9%, down 430 bps Y/Y but up 150 bps Q/Q and slightly above guidance of 33.5%. That contributed to Cree's big EPS beat, and is being well-received in light of the company's recent margin woes. GM is expected to slip to ~33.5% in seasonally weak FQ3.
    • Also boosting EPS: Cree spent $266M to buy back 8.1M shares. The company is three months removed from upping its FY15 buyback authorization to $550M.
    • Segment performance: LED product (chip/component) revenue -29% Y/Y to $151.9M (hurt by Chinese mid-power competition); gross margin -630 bps to 39.1%. Lighting product revenue +33% to $230.2M; gross margin +20 bps to 28.1%. Power/RF product revenue +18% to $31.1M; gross margin -250 bps to 55.5%.
    • GAAP SG&A spend +7% Y/Y to $72.4M; R&D +6% to $47M. Inventories rose by $21.8M Q/Q to $332.5M, and stood at 108 days.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM
  • IBKR

    Interactive Brokers -5.9% after earnings miss

    • Q4 EPS of $0.02 misses by $0.04.
    • Electronic Brokerage income of $166.9M vs. $49.2M a year ago on revenue of $261.5M vs. $212.1M. Total accounts of 281K vs. 239K. Total DARTs of 619K up 24% Y/Y. Commission per DART of $4.28 up 1%. Net revenue per average account (annualized) of $3.7K up 10%.
    • Market Making income of $15.1M vs. $29.4M a year ago on revenue of $53.6M vs. $76.2M. For the year, market making income fell 28% thanks to "persistent low volatility and intensive competition."
    • Conference call today at 4:30 ET
    • IBKR -5.9% after hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • NFLX

    Netflix higher after subscriber growth satisfies

    • Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) reports it added 1.90M net subscribers in the U.S. to edge its guidance of 1.85M and the consensus view of 1.83M.
    • International net subs added were 2.43M vs. 2.15M guided and 2.17M consensus.
    • Guidance for Q1 of 2015 is for 1.80M U.S. adds and 2.25M global.
    • Total streaming contribution margin +140 bps Y/Y and - 440 bps Q/Q to 13.6% as the company's entry into new markets was a factor.
    • Netflix says it will increase the percentage of original content spending over the next few years as new series continue to score highly.
    • Piracy issues in new European markets are noted.
    • Letter to shareholders (.pdf)
    • Previously: Netflix beats by $0.27, revenue in-line (Jan. 20)
    • NFLX +11.2% after-hours
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 9 Comments
  • WWD

    Woodward beats by $0.20, beats on revenue

    • Woodward (NASDAQ:WWD): FQ1 EPS of $0.66 beats by $0.20.
    • Revenue of $487.64M (+13.7% Y/Y) beats by $40.74M.
    • Shares +4.47%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM
  • SMCI

    Super Micro Computer beats by $0.18, beats on revenue

    • Super Micro Computer (NASDAQ:SMCI): FQ2 EPS of $0.65 beats by $0.18.
    • Revenue of $503M (+41.1% Y/Y) beats by $35.14M.
    • Shares +1.7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:09 PM | 1 Comment
  • NFLX

    Netflix beats by $0.27, revenue in-line

    • Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX): Q4 EPS of $0.72 beats by $0.27.
    • Revenue of $1.48B (+25.4% Y/Y) in-line.
    • Shares +9.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:06 PM | 17 Comments
  • CREE

    Cree beats by $0.11, beats on revenue

    • Cree (NASDAQ:CREE): FQ2 EPS of $0.33 beats by $0.11.
    • Revenue of $413.15M (-0.5% Y/Y) beats by $1.03M.
    • Shares +7.54%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:02 PM | 2 Comments
  • MHRCQ

    Magnum Hunter cut to Neutral from Buy at Sun Trust

    • Magnum Hunter Resources (MHR -15.5%) plunges to new 52-week lows as shares are downgraded to Neutral from Buy at Sun Trust Robinson Humphrey, which also lowered MHR's price target to $2.50 from $7.
    • The firm believes MHR will lower 2015 capex to improve its liquidity situation as commodity prices weigh on potential Bakken sales and the Eureka Hunter Midstream IPO.
    • MHR has been declining steadily during the past two months, falling 61% since Nov. 21.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • PNNT

    PennatPark Investment pops on preliminary results, dividend maintenance

    • PennantPark Investment (PNNT -2.4%) has erased a big chunk of a sizable move lower today after estimating Dec. 31 NAV of $10.40-$10.45 per share vs. the current price of $8.56.
    • Q4 net investment income is expected at $0.25-$0.27 per share, and the company anticipates maintaining the quarterly $0.28 payout.
    • Since quarter's end, one of PNNT's portfolio companies priced an IPO. Proceeds in Q1 should be about $60M, resulting in a realized gain of $0.13 per share, and a boost to NAV of $0.08. The company also expects about $0.04 of other income this quarter.
    • With the stock price nearly 20% below NAV, the company says it has no intention of issuing shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:51 PM | 3 Comments
  • TRQ

    Turquoise Hill says Mongolia mine concentrator output restored

    • Turquoise Hill (TRQ +6%) shoots higher following yesterday's report that the concentrator at the Oyu Tolgoi copper and gold mine in Mongolia has resumed full production following a fire in December.
    • The owner of two-thirds of Oyu Tolgoi also said it had produced 148.4K metric tons of of copper and 589K oz. of gold in concentrates in 2014, in line with company forecasts.
    • TRQ expects the mine to produce 175K-195K metric tons of copper and 600K-700K oz. of gold in concentrates in 2015, repeating forecasts it gave last month.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 1 Comment
  • PBR

    Petrobras to maintain prices, avoiding margin hit from taxes, UBS says

    • Petrobras (PBR -3.8%) will keep its fuel prices stable rather than cutting them to reduce the tax impact on consumers, UBS analyst Lilyanna Yang writes as she reiterates a Neutral rating on the ordinary shares following yesterday's announcement by Brazil Finance Minister Joaquin Levy that the country will raise revenue through two gasoline taxes starting in February.
    • "The fact that Petrobras is not cutting prices to make up for higher taxes is a sign that things are different," and will help boost investors’ confidence in the government’s efforts to balance Brazil's budget, says a partner at Brazilian hedge fund Teorica Investimentos.
    • Meanwhile, three workers were seriously hurt in an explosion Sunday at the company's 323K bbl/day Landulpho Alves Refinery, the second serious accident at Brazil's second-largest refinery in a week; PBR has not said if oil processing or fuel output at the refinery has been affected by the accident, but does say it will not affect fuel supplies to Brazilian consumers.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:22 PM | 2 Comments
  • PSX

    Barron's: Phillips 66 shares could rise sharply

    • Phillips 66 (PSX +3%) is outpacing most of its refining peers following a weekend Barron's report that says shares could rise 50% after a 30% drop amid the oil price swoon.
    • Using cash flow from refining, CEO Greg Garland is refashioning PSX into a giant that operates infrastructure for the transport, storage and processing of energy - all more profitable activities than refining, and all of which command higher valuations in the stock market.
    • PSX's businesses have been hammered in the oil rout but prices will not drop forever, and PSX "has a great balance sheet and the benefits of diversification in tough markets," says Tudor Pickering's Bradley Olsen, who thinks the stock is worth $94 on a sum of the parts based on his 2015 estimates.
    • J.P. Morgan analysts Phil Gresh and John Royall cite “the most diversified portfolio in the refining group, with the highest potential for more stable growth outside of refining" in calculating a price target of $74.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:40 PM | 13 Comments
  • SPCB

    SuperCom down 8.4% on strong volume

    • SuperCom (NASDAQ:SPCB) has tumbled towards $8 on a quiet day of trading for the Nasdaq. 263K shares have been traded thus far vs. a 3-month daily average of 160K.
    • The RFID tech provider is now down 20% from a Jan. 7 close of $10.05. Shares go for 2.5x 2015E sales; the 2-analyst revenue growth consensus is at 25.8%.
    • Previously: SuperCom buys cybersecurity services firm Prevision
     
     
     
     
    | 2:36 PM | 5 Comments
  • WDDD

    Patent stocks rally after Supreme Court's Teva ruling

    • Worlds (OTCQB:WDDD +11.9%), Spherix (SPEX +6.5%), Wi-LAN (WILN +7.2%), ParkerVision (OTC:PRKR +4.3%), and Finjan (FNJN +4.9%) have joined Vringo (previous) in rallying after the Supreme Court ruled (by a 7-2 margin) in Teva Pharmaceuticals' favor in a patent suit against generic drugmakers, reversing a federal appeals court ruling invalidating a Teva patent and sending it back for further review.
    • SA author Patent Plays thinks the ruling has big implications."The Supreme Court just eliminated a key power the US Court of Appeals has been frequently using in such cases as Vringo (VRNG), VirnetX, and many others. The ability to cast aside substantial evidence findings over the District Courts rule is effectively over ... This win cascades with ramifications to multiple PAE's (Patent Assertion Entities) with litigation pending and in force."
    • The S.C. decision follows a string of 2014 setbacks for patent licensing firms.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:15 PM | 3 Comments
  • DYN

    Dynegy delays power plant purchase, citing FERC inquiry

    • Dynegy (DYN -7.2%) is moving back plans to close two separate deals to buy 19 power plants from Duke Energy and Energy Capital Partners it announced in August until some time after March, following a FERC request for additional information about the transactions.
    • In a letter to the companies involved, the agency said it wants more information on how the transactions would affect electricity pricing in the PJM market, the power grid that serves much of the east coast including Pennsylvania, Maryland and Virginia.
    • DYN had believed it qualified for an exemption from conducting a "delivered price test" market analysis as part of its FERC application, but the agency disagreed and it instructed the company to conduct the test.
    • The $6.25B in deals would add 12.5K MW of power generation to DYN's fleet, nearly doubling its capacity to 26K MW and make DYN one of the largest U.S. power generators.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:08 PM
  • BCPC

    Balchem slides after new short report

    • Shares of Balchem (BCPC -7.9%) decline on heavy volume after Off Wall Street rates the company a Sell.
    • The research firm sets a $42 price target on the stock.
    • Concerns are raised on the impact to revenue from Balchem's fracking clients.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM
  • ARCT

    Money flow into Alcobra picks up

    • Thinly-traded nano cap Alcobra (ADHD +6.2%) continues its clawback from its late September-early October plunge. Shares plummeted 86% from the September intermediate high of $21.53 to the November 18 low of $3.12 but have more than doubled since then on increased volume.
    • Investors stampeded for the exits after the company reported Phase 3 data for Metadoxine Extended Release (MDX) in adults with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) that showed MDX failed to deliver a statistically significant improvement in efficacy versus placebo.
    • Alcobra was not be deterred, however. In a post-hoc analysis, eight patients (five from placebo, three MDX group) who violated entry criteria, based on ICH E9 guidelines, were excluded. This improved the results but still failed to achieve statistical significance.
    • Messaging the data still further, another post-hoc analysis excluded another two patients whose responses were more than three standard deviations away from the average response in the treatment group. The exclusion of the ten "outliers" enabled MDX to demonstrate a statistically significant improvement in efficacy compared to placebo.
    • Investors apparently are warming to the company's approach to data analysis and perceive improved prospects for MDX, buoyed by the recent capital raise.
    • Previously: Alcobra's Metadoxine trial fails to show efficacy vs. placebo, share down AH (Oct. 22, 2014)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:50 PM
  • OWW

    Orbitz +12.6%; company reportedly exploring sale

    • Bloomberg reports Orbitz (NYSE:OWW) is exploring a sale. Shares have jumped above $10 in response.
    • The scoop comes ahead of Orbitz's Q4 report. Larger rivals Priceline and Expedia have been outgrowing the company in recent years.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:47 PM
  • BABA

    Alibaba rallies towards $100

    • After having fallen 8% over the prior five trading days, Alibaba (BABA +2.9%) is posting solid gains on a day the Nasdaq is near breakeven. Volume is moderate - 8.4M shares thus far vs. a 3-month daily average of 14.4M.
    • Recent news: 1) As part of its efforts to help U.S. retailers sell to Chinese consumers (previous), Alibaba and Alipay have struck deals with Macy's, Saks, Aeropostale, and Gilt Group to handle China-related payments and shipping. 2) Alibaba has signed an MOU with Indian trade group CII to work on facilitating trade between Chinese and Indian SMBs. 3) Continuing its VC investing spree, Alibaba has reportedly invested $6M in Israeli QR code-scanning tech developer Visualead.
    • FQ3 results arrive in nine days.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM | 7 Comments
  • SPLS

    FT: Staples to resist Starboard call for ODP merger

    • Staples (SPLS -5.5%) isn't likely to pursue a plan to combine with Office Depot (ODP -4.7%), according to Financial Times.
    • The company has concerns the FTC would put up stiff resistance to a merger.
    • Previously: Report: Starboard pushing for Staples-Office Depot merger (Jan. 20)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:28 PM
  • IPIX

    Cellceutix up on report of positive results in clinical trial

    • Micro cap Cellceutix (CTIX +17.8%) jumps on a 2x surge in volume in response to its announcement of the complete disappearance of a metastatic lesion in the spleen of a Stage 4 ovarian cancer patient who was enrolled in the company's Phase 1 study of Kevetrin. The patient completed three cycles of treatment (three doses per cycle) before discontinuing the trial. Scans of the spleen showed the lesion to be essentially undetectable and the patient's disease clinically stable. The clinical trial is ongoing.
    • Kevetrin is a small molecule drug that induces the activation of p53, a tumor suppressor protein often referred to as the "Guardian Angel Gene" because of its prominent role in controlling cell mutations.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM | 14 Comments
  • CYOU

    Sohu +7.5% on strong volume; Changyou +3.3%

    • Beaten-down SOHU is among the standouts on a fairly quiet day for tech. The Chinese search/gaming/video provider has seen 348K shares trade thus far, surpassing a 3-month daily average of 307K. Online gaming subsidiary Changyou (NASDAQ:CYOU) is also having a good day.
    • Sohu sports a 2015E EV/sales ratio of just 0.6x. Given history, Sohu and Changyou's Q4 results will likely arrive in late January or early February.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:10 PM
  • MT

    ArcelorMittal to sell sole Russian asset

    • ArcelorMittal (MT +2.5%) says it is selling its interest in the Kuzbass coal mines in Siberia to Russia's National Fuel Company, part of its strategic decision to source coal from Kazakhstan for steel operations in Ukraine.
    • Financial terms were not disclosed, but MT bought the two mines from Russian steel producer Severstal for $652M in 2008, when they produced a combined 1.8M metric tons/year of concentrate; production fell to 677K metric tons in 2013.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • INWK

    InnerWorkings plunges after announcing CFO's departure

    • Joseph Busky, InnerWorkings' (INWK -13%) CFO since 2008, is leaving to "pursue other business opportunities." He'll remain on board through the filing of the company's 2014 10-K.
    • Controller Ryan Spohn has been named interim CFO. The announcement comes ahead of InnerWorkings' Feb. 12 Q4 report.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM | 1 Comment
  • ILMN

    Ilumina up on genome project speculation

    • Ilumina (ILMN +5.8%) moves north on a 50% spike in volume as speculation builds that President Obama will announce a government-funded project to sequence 1M human genomes during his State of the Union speech this evening.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM | 3 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: CNET +26%. DRD +15%. LEDS +15%. SWHC +15%. QLTI +14%. OIBR-C +13%. RLJE +13%. ALDX +13%. THTI +12%. OIBR +11%.
    • Losers: GTE -36%. ASPS -18%. OUTR -16%. IGTE -16%. EXPR -16%. MHR -15%. BAK -14%. OTC:VLTC -14%. OTC:BONT -14%. INWK -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • GTE

    Gran Tierra -35% after wells disappoint, eyes cut to reserves estimates

    • Gran Tierra Energy (GTE -35.2%) plunges to 52-week lows after saying its 2014 production averaged 25.2K boe/day, or 19.3K boe/day net after royalties before adjusting for inventory changes and losses.
    • GTE says it found no commercial hydrocarbons at its Eslabón Sur exploration well in Colombia.
    • GTE also says Block 95 at the Bretaña Field in Peru encountered disappointing oil pay results and expects to remove the possible reserves that were booked for the field, as well as a reduction in probable reserves for the field.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • JKS

    Chinese solar stocks off sharply

    • Chinese solar plays JinkoSolar (JKS -6.7%), ReneSola (SOL -3.9%), JA Solar (JASO -3.5%), Daqo (DQ -9.3%), and Trina (previously covered) are posting sizable losses. As is Canadian Solar (CSIQ -10%), which depends heavily on its Chinese manufacturing ops.
    • The decline comes as WTI crude oil falls by 3.7% to $46.89/barrel, and Henry Hub natural gas falls by 8.6% to $2.86/mmBtu. Also: The Shanghai exchange fell 7.5% on Monday following 3-month ban on new margin trading accounts, before rising 1.8% today. The Nasdaq is currently down 0.3%.
    • Saudi Arabia has provided a bit of bad news, stating it's pushing back the completion date for its massive clean energy program (includes $109B worth of solar investments) by 8 years to 2040. Unlike many of its top energy customers, Saudi Arabia depends heavily on oil (suddenly much cheaper) for electricity production.
    • U.S. solar stocks are also underperforming, but less dramatically. The Guggenheim Solar ETF (TAN -2.3%) is less than $0.30 away from its 52-week low of $31.77.
    • Update: Also potentially hurting: A Chinese government study found 23% of solar panel samples taken from local firms featured glass coating defects that can affect long-term power efficiency. The defects were in products set to be used in China.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:40 PM | 22 Comments
  • RTEC

    Rudolph up 3.9% on Barrington upgrade

    • Barrington Research's Ted Moreau, Jr. has upgraded Rudolph Technologies (NASDAQ:RTEC) to Outperform ahead of its Feb. 2 Q4 report, and set a $12.50 target.
    • Moreau: "When we updated our thoughts on our two semiconductor capital equipment stocks two weeks ago, we expressed continued concern about lingering softness for their back-end business. Since then, TSMC raised their 2015 capex budget by nearly $2 billion and we have grown more confident of Samsung's 14nm position in 2015. As such, we believe 2015 will be a good year for Rudolph's front-end business and so are raising our 2015 estimates."
    • Previously: Chip equipment makers take Intel/TSMC's capex budgets in stride
     
     
     
     
    | 12:23 PM
  • BGCP

    BGC Partners boosts GFI Group bid once more

    • BGC Partners (BGCP -2.4%) lifts its price for GFI Group (GFIG +5.7%) to $6.10 per share in cash, and extends the expiration date to February 3.
    • The price is about 4% higher than the latest cash and stock deal offered by CME Group and GFI management.
    • Should GFI accept the deal by midnight tonight, BGC will add another $0.10 per share to its offer.
    • GFI is currently trading at $5.91.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:14 PM
  • XSPA

    Vringo up 14.6% after Teva verdict

    • By a 7-2 margin, the Supreme Court has ruled in favor of Teva Pharmaceuticals in its patent suit against generic drugmakers, thereby reversing a federal appeals court (CAFC) decision that declared a patent in dispute was invalid, and sending the case back for further review.
    • Vringo (VRNG) appears to have gotten a lift from the ruling. The company is a month removed from stating it will seek a Supreme Court review of the CAFC's adverse ruling against Vringo regarding its infringement suit against Google, after the CAFC denied a petition for an en banc review of its decision. (hat tip: Patent Plays)
    • Shares are still down 82% from where they traded prior to the Google ruling.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:14 PM | 37 Comments
  • XENE

    Xenon off on profit taking

    • Recent IPO Xenon Pharmaceuticals (XENE -14.1%) succumbs to profit taking today. The move is due. Shares had climbed 160% from the $9 offer price, peaking at $23.50 on January 9.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM
  • TAHO

    Tahoe Resources reports 2014 production at high end of expectations

    • Tahoe Resources (TAHO +3%) reports FY 2014 production of 20.3M oz. of silver from its Escobal mine. at the high end of expectations, and forecasts 2015 silver production of 18M-21M oz.
    • TAHO says year-end silver production was particularly strong, resulting in a December surplus of unsold concentrates that increased normal inventory by 1M oz. that will be sold to customers in Q1 2015.
    • After starting the Escobal mine's first year of production on time and meeting production and cost goals, TAHO says the second year of full production will focus on optimizing operating performance and costs.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM
  • SABA

    Saba up 18.5% after disclosing M&A interest

    • Following talks with "a number of strategic and financial parties," OTCPK:SABA Software "has received multiple non-binding indications of interest regarding a potential acquisition of the Company."
    • The company "anticipates being in a position to enter into a definitive agreement prior to February 15, 2015 if the Board of Directors determines to pursue a sale transaction." Morgan Stanley continues to advise.
    • Saba first disclosed its strategic review on Dec. 16, in tandem with a less-than-cheerful business/accounting review update.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:53 AM
  • ADPT

    Adaptus pulls back

    • Thinly-traded Adaptus Health (ADPT -9.1%) drops on 50% higher volume albeit on turnover of only 150K shares. No particular news accounts for the move although the stock has been rolling over from its peak of $38.78 on December 18 and retest on January 5.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:43 AM
  • OUTR

    Outerwall CEO resigns; shares slide

    • Outerwall (OUTR -14.6%) trades lower after CEO J. Scott Di Valerio resigns from his position and the board.
    • The company has begun a search process for a replacement.
    • In addition, Outerwall is out with updated guidance. Q4 revenue of $598M-$602M vs. $596M consensus expected and EPS of $2.40-$2.52 vs. $2.06 consensus.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:37 AM | 6 Comments
  • CHK

    Chesapeake Energy bumps up after M&A chatter

    • Chesapeake Energy (CHK +1.9%) moves higher as a report speculates that the company could be a potential acquisition target of India's ONGC.
    • India's government has directed state-run ONGC to make some acquisitions to hedge themselves against higher energy prices in the future, and reportedly considers CHK a strong strategic target, given its recent sales, balance sheet and diversification through two commodities.
    • The report says ONGC could already be in talks with a North American gas and oil company, with CHK believed to be the target.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:33 AM | 20 Comments
  • MCRL

    Micrel up 5.8% on strategic review

    • Micrel's (NASDAQ:MCRL) board has "unanimously decided to undertake a comprehensive review of strategic alternatives to enhance value for shareholders."
    • A Transactions Committee composed of three directors has been formed, and Credit Suisse hired to advise.
    • Plenty of other chipmakers have been acquired over the last 15 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:58 AM
  • BCEI

    Bonanza Creek to cut 2015 capex by 36%-38%

    • Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI -7.5%) says it will cut 2015 capital spending by 36%-38% Y/Y and invest $420M in its projects in the Wattenberg field and Arkansas.
    • BCEI says the budget will maintain its 2014 exit rate sales volumes through the full year, achieving ~15% Y/Y annual growth.
    • Expects to spend ~$380M in the Wattenberg field to achieve sales volumes of 23.7M boe/day for the year, ~23% growth.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:49 AM
  • TSL

    Trina appoints COO; shares -5.7%

    • Zhiguo Zhu, formerly the head of Trina's (NYSE:TSL) Module Business Unit, has been promoted to the newly-created position of COO. He'll now be responsible for "leading the Company's environmental health and safety management system and the establishment of the Company's performance excellence management system," while maintaining his prior responsibilities.
    • Trina also says it has appointed Sean Shao, the company's CFO from 2006-2008, to its board and audit committee. Separately, the company has unveiled new high-efficiency modules that respectively sport average cell efficiencies of 18.7% and 20.4%.
    • Trina is joining other solar stocks in selling off amid a fresh decline in oil prices.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:47 AM | 1 Comment

  • SPDR Gold Trust assets surge

    • Gold holdings in the SPDR Gold Trust (GLD +1.3%) jumped by 1.9% on Friday to 730.89 metric tons - the biggest one-day gain in nearly five years. For the week, holdings rose 3.3%.
    • Not surprisingly, the jump in assets came alongside a nice run higher in price for the metal - now up nearly 10% on the year.
    • ETFs: GLD, IAU, SGOL, UGL, DGP, GLL, UGLD, DZZ, GLDI, OUNZ, DGL, DGZ, DGLD, AGOL, TBAR, UBG, GLDE, BAR, GYEN, GEUR, BARS, GGBP
     
     
     
     
    | 10:45 AM | 9 Comments
  • EHTH

    EHealth up in early trading

  • CEL

    Cellcom, Partner plunge after Golan unveils new plan

    • Upstart Golan Telecom has rolled out a mobile service plan for large and mid-sized businesses that costs just NIS25/month ($6.40/month) per phone. Golan will also charge VAT and a flat fee of NIS250/month for all the lines bought by a business (up to 500). Businesses have to buy at least 50 lines to qualify.
    • Cellcom (CEL -10.2%) and Partner (PTNR -7.4%), whose shares have already been battered on account of Israel's ongoing mobile price war, are falling hard once more. Both carriers sold off last week following the results of Israel's 4G spectrum auction.
    • Over the weekend, Cellcom announced a debt refinancing effort: The company is offering to exchange every NIS1 of its series D debt (up to NIS293M) for NIS1.45 worth of series H debt, and every NIS1 of its series E debt (up to NIS130M) for NIS1.16 worth of series I debt.

  • MU

    Micron up 2.1% on Susquehanna upgrade (updated)

    • Citing positive checks, Susquehanna has upgraded Micron (NASDAQ:MU) to Positive, and upped its target by $7 to $38.
    • The upgrade follows seven months during which Micron has largely moved sideways, after soaring from late 2012 to mid-2014. Shares slipped two weeks ago due to Micron's light FQ2 guidance, and last week due to a Samsung DRAM expansion report. They now go for 7x estimated FY16 (ends Aug. '16) EPS.
    • Update: More details here. Susquehanna's checks point to embedded NAND share gains "particularly in China and in mid-to-low-end smartphones where growth is higher than the high end market," something it expects will boost Micron's NAND margins. DRAM margins are expected to further rise in 2H15 thanks to a mix shift towards server and DDR4 DRAM. DRAM wafer capacity is expected to grow at a moderate 5% annual clip.

  • BHGE

    Baker Hughes beats expectations, to cut 7,000 employees

    • Baker Hughes (BHI) +1.6% premarket after easily beating Q4 earnings estimates but warning of a difficult 2015, similar to concerns discussed today in Halliburton's earnings report.
    • "While market demand ended up being more resilient in the fourth quarter than many had predicted, the recent declines seen in rig counts will clearly affect results in 2015," BHI CEO Martin Craighead says.
    • Q4 revenue at BHI's North American segment jumped 20.4% to $3.3B, Middle East/Asia Pacific revenue rose 13%, Europe/Africa/Russia added 5%, and Latin America revenue slipped 2%.
    • BHI says it realized its best pressure pumping margins in three years and hit its goal of mid-teens operating margins in North America; international results exceeded forecasts, driven by a surge in year-end product sales.
    • Says it will lay off 7,000 employees, mostly in the current quarter, and is reviewing its facilities for possible closures; expects to book a one-time charge of $160M-$185M.
    • On Friday, activist investor ValueAct Capital Management reported a 5.1% stake in BHI, an unusual move since the company is being bought by Halliburton; ValueAct began buying the week after the deal was announced in November.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:37 AM
  • LUK-OLD

    FXCM details rescue package

    • The credit agreement with Leucadia (NYSE:LUK-OLD) is for a $300M two-year loan, with net proceeds to FXCM of $279M covering the negative client balances generated by the massive swings in the Swiss franc late last week.
    • The loan carries an interest rate of 10%, increasing by 1.5% annually until it's paid off (with a 17% cap).
    • The deal also essentially gives Leucadia much of the equity in the business, and it will get 50% of any dividend or sale proceeds up to $350M, then 90% for certain amounts above that, and 60% at another higher level of proceeds (all coming after the loan is paid off, of course).
    • FXCM is off 90% (from its Thursday close) premarket to $1.26.
    • Previous coverage of the saga
     
     
     
     
    | 8:37 AM | 4 Comments
